Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Northwest Vista College (NVC) is implementing Project ION (Improving Opportunities in Nanotechnology) to support the educational preparation of technicians for our nation's nanotechnology fields. The project is helping NVC use innovative linkages with high schools, four-year institutions, and industry partners to increase the number of technicians with current knowledge and skills entering the nanotechnology workforce. Project ION's activities are being guided by the objectives of innovation, implementation and regional adaptation. Project ION is demonstrating effective ways that two-year institutions can creatively lead partnerships with four-year institutions, research organizations, and industry partners to provide nanotechnology-related learning, research, and career development activities for STEM students. It is also creating new models for nanotechnology-focused workforce development activities for underserved populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2012, Northwest Vista College (NVC) was awarded a 3-year NSF grant: Improving Opportunities in Nanotechnology (Project ION #1205010) to increase the number of technicians with 21st century knowledge and skills entering the nanotechnology workforce. To accomplish this goal, the project focused on testing and evaluating new curricula, hands-on laboratory experiments, summer institute programs, professional development for high school and community college faculty, and remote instruction.  In addition, Project ION focused on community outreach and awareness of nanotechnology through the development of cutting edge classroom activities, internship opportunities, memorandum of agreements with potential employers, and career placement—with an additional aim of determining best practices for pursuing the development of a future ATE Projects grant.

Over the past 3 years, project leadership successfully created a foundation of proven best practices; enhanced NVC’s inter-connected networks of support and resource sharing among the formal education system, research and development organizations, and industry, and piloted a robust high school and community college faculty professional development program.  These activities helped NVC to generate new interest in high-tech STEM disciplines. In addition, these activities have prepared educators to integrate Nanotechnology into classrooms, and plan for regional and statewide expansion of our education program.  A summary of accomplishments and activities delineating the impact of Project ION include:

Program Development and Improvement

  • A formal 10 member San Antonio Nanotechnology Forum (SANTF) Committee was established in the greater San Antonio area.
  • 154 students participated in Remote Access laboratory project that was piloted through NACK center at local high schools/districts;
  • 20 high school students attended in the week-long Summer Nanotechnology Institute;
  • Six students participated in hands-on research and project based internship program with Southwest Research Institute;
  • Over 200 High School students visited Nanotechnology Table during College and Career Fest at Southwest Independent School District (ISD);
  • 46 student members joined a Nanotechnology Club that was established at Southwest high school;
  • 300 students participated in Nanotechnology Day at Natalie High school;
  • 50 students visited Nanotechnology table during Career Day at Holmes high school;
  • Three NVC students were selected to attend NanoJapan Program that was hosted by Rice University as part of a NSF grant;
  • Two NVC students were accepted into the National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network (NNIN) Research Experience for Undergraduates Program;
  • Five students earned a Student Award for Excellence by the NSF at Annual ATE PI Conference;
  • Mentoring and partnership opportunities were utilized from two existing ATE Centers to develop Project ION as the first phase of a program that engages high school students and educators in nanotechnology learning activities;

Professional Development for Educators

  • 15 high school and community college STEM faculty participated in the week-long summer “Educate the Educators” workshop in 2013, in which 11 faculty Cohort returned subsequent year in 2014.
  • 14 high school and community college faculty participated in a Remote Access workshop.
